{{Use Australian English|date=September 2016}} {{Use DMY dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox comics character and title | character_name = Captain Atom | image = Captain Atom, Atlas Publications, Issue 1, 1948.jpg | caption = {{Descript-cvr|Captain Atom||1|1948|art=[[Arthur Mather]]|pub=Atlas Publications}} | publisher = '''Original:'''
[[Atlas Publications]]
'''Current:'''
Meteor Comics | debut = '''Captain Atom'''
#1 (January 1948) | creators = [[Jack Bellew]] (writer)
[[Arthur Mather]] (artist) | alter_ego = | full_name = | species = | homeworld = | alliances = | partners = Dr Bikini Rador (aka Larry Lockhart) | supports = | aliases = The Atomic Warrior, the Atom Man, Atoman | powers = * [[Superhuman]] strength * Superhuman speed * Flight * Emit atomic heat/fusion blasts (hands) * Focused air blasts (breath) * Near invulnerability |title = Captain Atom |cvr_image = |cvr_caption = |cvr_alt = |schedule = Monthly |format = |limited = |ongoing = n |1shot = |Superhero = y |pub_series = '''Captain Atom'''
[[Atlas Publications]]
'''Vixen'''
Meteor Comics |date = |1stishhead = Captain Atom No. 1 |1stishyr = 1948 |1stishmo = January |endishyr = 1954 |endishmo = May |1stishhead1 = Vixen No. 1 |1stishyr1 = 1995 |1stishmo1 = May |endishyr1 = |endishmo1 = |issues = 64 |main_char_team = |writers = |artists = |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators_series = |TPB = |ISBN = |nonUS = |cat = super |subcat = |altcat = |hero = y |villain = |sortkey = Captain Atom |sort_title = Captain Atom }} '''''Captain Atom''''' was an [[Comics in Australia|Australian comic book]] series created and written by [[Jack Bellew]] with illustrations by [[Arthur Mather]].Arnold, John and Hay, John A. (2001). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YgX_TOK9xa4C&pg=PA332&lpg=PA332 "Mather, Arthur"]. ''The Bibliography of Australian Literature'', Vol. 3, pp. 332–333. University of Queensland Press. {{ISBN|0702235989}} It was published from 1948 to 1954, with 64 issues{{cite web|url=http://www.comics.org/series/75660/|title=Captain Atom (Atlas)|publisher=[[Grand Comics Database]]|accessdate=30 September 2016}} and it also appeared as strips in a number of Australian newspapers. The protagonist, the first to use the name, has no relation to the later American superhero [[Captain Atom]], published by [[Charlton Comics]] in 1965{{cite web|url=http://www.comics.org/series/1667/|title=Captain Atom (Charlton)|publisher=[[Grand Comics Database]]|accessdate=30 September 2016}} and subsequently by [[DC Comics]] in 1987.{{cite web|url=http://www.comics.org/series/3349/|title=Captain Atom (DC)|publisher=[[Grand Comics Database]]|accessdate=30 September 2016}} == Background == The fledgling publishing company [[Atlas Publications]] achieved its first major success with its ''Captain Atom''. It was drawn by Arthur Mather,{{cite web|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/m/mather_arthur.htm|title=Arthur Mather|publisher=[[Lambiek#Lambiek website|Lambiek Comiclopedia]] |date=18 May 2007|accessdate=30 September 2016}} who like [[Yaroslav Horak]] and [[Andrea Bresciani]], became a regular artist for Atlas. The character was co-created and written by [[Jack Bellew]] under the pen name "John Welles". The character is based on a combination of [[Fawcett Publications]]' [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]] and [[Quality Comics]]' [[Captain Triumph]] (first published in 1941 and 1943 respectively).{{Cite book|title=Panel by Panel – An Illustrated history of Australian Comics|author1=Ryan, John|page=190|date=1979 |publisher=Cassell Australia |isbn=0-7269-7376-9 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ncs.net.au/who-were-the-australian-superheroes-and-where-have-they-gone/|title=Who were the Australian superheroes and where have they gone?|publisher=Network Creative Services Pty Ltd |date=29 June 2016|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The character's origin had identical twin brothers being caught in an atomic bomb blast and becoming fused into one, with Dr. Bikini Rador (a nuclear physicist) being the dominant persona. By shouting the magic word, ''Exenor!'', Rador transforms into his now atomic-powered twin. Rador takes on the identity of Larry Lockhart, an [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent, to fight crime, switching places with his brother when situations call for a superhero.{{cite web|url=http://www.themarysue.com/agent-of-style-captain-atom-part-1/|title=Agent of S.T.Y.L.E. – Captain Atom’s Atomic Ensemble!|last=Kistler|first=Alan|publisher=''[[Dan Abrams#The Mary Sue|The Mary Sue]]''|date=29 May 2014|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/c/capatom.htm|title=Captain Atom|publisher=International Catalogue of Superheroes|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The comic was originally published entirely in colour, but Atlas followed its chief rival, [[K.G. Murray Publishing Company|K.G. Murray]], and switched to black and white two years later when the cost of colour printing became prohibitive. Despite the switch to black and white, the ''Captain Atom'' series remained successful, running to 64 issues over the next six years.Burrows, Toby and Stone, Grant (1994). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=aINij9gO6ccC&pg=PA32 ''Comics in Australia and New Zealand: The Collections, the Collectors, the Creators''], p. 32. Psychology Press. {{ISBN|1560246642}}[[National Library of Australia]]. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/version/38427324 Record 38427324]. Retrieved 24 September 2016.Sullivan, Jane (18 November 2006). [http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?page=1&sy=nstore&kw=Jack+Bellew&pb=all_ffx&dt=selectRange&dr=entire&so=relevance&sf=text&sf=headline&rc=200&rm=200&sp=nrm&clsPage=1&docID=AGE061118GFJ4KJCCMMT "When Captain Atom fought for innocence"]. ''[[The Age]]'', A2, p. 28Patrick, Kevin (November 2012). [http://www.participations.org/Volume%209/Issue%202/10%20Patrick.pdf "'Phans', not Fans”: The Phantom and Australian comic-book fandom"]. ''Participations: Journal of Audience and Reception Studies'', Vol. 9, No. 2, pp. 133–158 The first issue of ''Captain Atom'', which was released in January 1948{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookdb.com/issue.php?ID=315353|title=Captain Atom (1948) – #1|publisher=The Comicbook database|accessdate=30 September 2016}} sold approximately 100,000 copies{{cite web|archiveurl=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/44356/20040907-0000/www.statelibrary.vic.gov.au/slv/experimedia/digital-ink/forgottenheroes/o02.html|url=http://www.statelibrary.vic.gov.au/slv/experimedia/digital-ink/forgottenheroes/o02.html|title=Heroes and villans : Australian comics and their creators|publisher=State Library|archivedate=7 September 2004|accessdate=30 September 2016}} and at its peak was selling 180,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/152957-the-weird-and-wonderful-world-of-australian-comics/|title=The Weird and Wonderful World of Australian Comics|last=Maynard|first=Amy|work=[[PopMatters]]|publisher=PopMatters Media Inc.|date=10 July 2012|accessdate=30 September 2016}} Early issues featured backup stories provided by Mather (''Dopey Dan''), [[Stan Pitt]] (''Jim Atlas'', ''Dr Peril of Igogo'') and Michael Trueman (''Crackajack – Daredevil Trapeze Star''). Captain Atom was one of the few original Australian comic heroes to have his own merchandising and fan club. In the 1950s the fan club boasted that it had "over 75,000 members". The character was revived in 1985 and again in 2016 by [[Gerald Carr (cartoonist)|Gerald Carr]], appearing in Meteor Comics' ''[[Vixen (Australian comics)|Vixen]]''.''Vixen Magazine''. [http://www.vixenmagazine.com/CAPATOM.html Great Australian Comic Book Creations: "Captain Atom"] Captain Atom, renamed as the Atomic Warrior, featured alongside another 1950s Australian comic book hero, The Panther (created by [[Paul Wheelahan]]), and Carr's Vixen and Brainmaster. There is a visual reference to Captain Atom in the Watchmen comic book. In the origin story of Dr Manhattan (who is based on the Charlton Comics Captain Atom), the character is shown rejecting a helmet which is part of his US Government-supplied costume. The helmet design and the overall costume, although a different colour, somewhat resemble that of the Atlas Comics Captain Atom. The British artist, Dave Gibbons, may have been familiar with the Australian character. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *Patrick, Kevin (2004). [https://web.archive.org/web/20120225071834/http://pulpfaction.net/arthur_mather_0205 "Arthur Mather: Man of the Atom"] (archived copy of a lengthy interview with Mather, originally published on ''Pulp Faction'') *{{Citation | author1=Bellew, Jack, (author) | author2=Mather, Arthur, (artist) | title=Captain Atom | publication-date=1948 | publisher=Melbourne Atlas Publications | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/31684478 | accessdate=30 September 2016 }} [[Category:Australian comics titles]] [[Category:Male characters in comics]] [[Category:Australian comics characters]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1948]] [[Category:Comics characters with superhuman strength]] [[Category:Fictional characters who can move at superhuman speeds]]

revision.text:
A '''color suite''' (also called a '''color bay''', '''telecine suite''', or '''color correction bay''') is the [[control room]] for [[color grading]] [[video]] in a [[post-production]] environment.
==Technology and specifications== The video source could be from: a [[telecine]], a [[video tape recorder]] (VTR), a [[motion picture film scanner]], [[virtual telecine]] or a [[Direct to Disk Recording]] (DDR) or the older system called a [[film chain]]. A high end [[Broadcasting|broadcast]] color suite may use a [[Da Vinci Systems]] or [[Pandora International]]'s color corrector. If a VTR is the source for the video the room is often called a ''tape to tape'' suite. Many suites are designed to operate as a telecine suite or a tape to tape suite by changing the configuration of the suite. The operator of the suite is usually called a ''Colorist''. If a telecine is the source this is called a ''Film to Tape'' operation. A color suite may use one [[Video formats|video standard]] or be able to change configuration to a number of standards like: [[high-definition video]], [[NTSC]], or [[PAL]] or a [[digital intermediate|DI]] workflow. Color suites are sometime placed in [[digital cinema]] [[movie theaters]] with a [[video projector]] for color correction to that [[Image resolution|display format]].
The suite room will also have video equipment in the [[Production control room]] for monitoring the video signal like: [[Video monitor]], [[Waveform monitor]] and [[vectorscope]].
[[Image:Telecine site 1.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A Shadow Telecine in a color correction suite.]]
The suite may have an either a [[Non-linear editing system]] (NLE) or [[Linear editing]] system to control the source and record device. This may be internal to the color grading device, as in a Pandora's poggle or Da Vinci's 2k or external, as in Da Vinci's TLC (telecine controller).
A [[vision mixer]] may also be in the suite for monitoring different video sources or for simple or [[special effect]]s in the video. A [[character generator]] is sometime used also for titling and [[Subtitle (titling)|subtitle]].
The suite may have equipment to read, log and insert into the video Kodak's [[Keykode]]. Keykode is bar coding that is placed at regular intervals on negative films to aid in identifying and counting of film frames. Evertz, [[Aaton]] and [[ARRI]] are three types of readers for telecine use.
The suite may or may not have [[audio post production]] equipment. This would be to monitor and if needed sync up the [[Sound film#Technology|program audio]] to the video source if the sound was not on [[Sound-on-film|the film]]. An audio [[mixing console]] and other [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio equipment]] such as effects devices may also be in the suite. The audio may be from the [[film soundtrack]]. The term [[MOS (film)|MOS]] is used, on a [[clapperboard|slate]], when a scene is filmed without sync sound or any sound. A clapperboard slate is used at the start and sometime at the end of scene to mark particular takes recorded during a production.
Other equipment that may be used in the suite are: digital still store\[[Frame grabber]] to store references frames, [[Noise reduction|noise reducer]] to reduce film grain/dirt and [[Signal-to-noise ratio|video noise]]; [[video router]] and [[audio router]].
The telecine, VTRs and some of the larger equipment are often placed in a [[central apparatus room]] or ''machine room'' and are interconnected through [[Cable tray]]s or [[raised floor]] to the color suite by [[patch panel]]s, [[Coaxial cable]]s, [[Computer network]] and [[Multicore cable]]s.
Some color suites are at video post production facilities that rent them by the hour for the transfer of [[TV commercials]], [[Documentary film|documentaries]] and [[movies]]. These color suites would have a client area behind the colorist. With the [[Customer|client]] present this would be called a supervised session.
[[Image:SDC-2000 Spirit DataCine Telecine.JPG|right|thumb|250px|SDC-2000 [[Spirit DataCine]] Film Deck, Lens Gate and Local Control Panel]]
<gallery> Image:Da Vinci Impresario - control panel.jpg|Da Vinci Systems, Joy ball [[Mixing console|control panel]] Image:Cc2kdui.JPG|Da Vinci Systems, 2k [[GUI]] Display </gallery>
[[Image:BetacamSP VTRs.jpg|thumb|250px|BVW-75, PVW-2800, and UVW-1800 BetacamSP VTRs in a 19-inch racks.]]
[[Image:Sony BetacamSP BVW-75 Editing VTR.jpg|thumb|250px|Sony BetacamSP BVW-75 Editing [[VTR]] in a 19-inch rack.]]
== See also == * [[Test film]] * [[3D LUT]] * [[Cintel]], telecine equipment. * [[Color motion picture film]] * [[Da Vinci Systems]] * [[Pandora International]] * [[Digital intermediate]] * [[Display resolution]] * [[Faroudja]], inventors of reverse telecine technologies. * [[Film recorder]] * [[Film restoration]] * [[Film-out]] * [[Gamma correction]] * [[Hard disk recorder]] * [[HDTV blur]] Factors causing HDTV Blur * [[Image scanner]] * [[Telecine (piracy)]], an unauthorized copy of a film created with a telecine. * [[Telerecording]] (UK) * [[Television]]
== References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110527184115/http://www.technicolor.com/en/hi/broadcast/broadcast-post-production Technicolor’s Post production Facility], Technicolor, October 31, 2006 *[http://creativemac.digitalmedianet.com/articles/viewarticle.jsp?id=28880 Nice Shoes Adds Fourth Telecine Suite], creativemac.digitalmedianet.com, November 1, 2004{{Dead link|date=June 2018}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080108231322/http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/commercial/telecineprocedures.htm UCLA Film and Television Archive] UCLA, visited January 15, 2008 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110807134111/http://digitalintermediates.digitalmedianet.com/articles/viewarticle.jsp?id=43800-0 Postworks Opens Fifth Telecine Suite], digitalmedianet.com, May 23, 2006 *[http://filmsound.org/terminology/mos.htm Film Sound Terminology]
{{VideoProcessing}}

[[File:Extraschicht 2011-Nordsternpark-Urbanatix101104 - cropped.jpg|thumb|Urbanatix performer in Nordsternpark at Ruhr's 2011 ExtraSchicht festival]] [[File:Roni & Cyr Wheel C IMG 2524.JPG|thumb|Street performer during Kerava's 2013 Sirkusmarkkinoilla (Circus Festival)]]
The '''Cyr wheel''' (also known as the '''roue Cyr''', '''mono wheel''',<ref name="monowheel">{{cite web | url = http://www.gymmedia.com/wheel-gymnastics/real-History-Mono-Wheel-Cyr-Wheel | title = The real History of Mono Wheel (Cyr Wheel) | publisher = GymMedia.com | date = 29 December 2012 | accessdate = 28 October 2015 }}</ref> or '''simple wheel''') is an acrobatic apparatus that consists of a single large ring made of aluminum or steel with a diameter approximately {{convert|10|to|15|cm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} taller than the performer.<ref name="FEDEC">{{cite web | url = http://www.fedec.eu/datas/files/fedec_cyrwheelmanual_en_2011.pdf | format = PDF | title = Cyr Wheel: Instruction Manual | publisher = European Federation of Professional Circus Schools (FEDEC) | date = 2011 | pages = 7-10 | accessdate = 28 October 2015 }}</ref><ref name="inertie">{{cite web|url=http://www.inertie.ca/historique_roue.php |title=Historique Roue Cyr (in English) |publisher=inertie.ca |accessdate=2015-10-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315162338/http://inertie.ca/historique_roue.php |archivedate=2016-03-15 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The performer stands inside the Cyr wheel and grasps its rim, causing it to roll and spin gyroscopically while performing acrobatic moves in and around the rotating wheel. The apparatus and its movement vocabulary have some similarities with the [[German wheel]], but whereas the German wheel consists of two large rings linked together by horizontal crossbars and has handles for the performer to hold onto, the modern Cyr wheel consists of a single ring and has no handles.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rhoenrad.com/en/about.html | title = About Wheel Gymnastics | publisher = International Wheel Gymnastics Federation | accessdate = 28 October 2015 }}</ref> The Cyr wheel takes its name from Daniel Cyr, who reinvented it as a [[circus]] apparatus at the end of the 20th century.
There are records of people using a similar apparatus as sports equipment during the mid-20th century in Germany,<ref name="monowheel"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rhoenrad-dtb.de/2012/irv-nimmt-mono-wheel-in-wm-programm-auf.html | title = IRV nimmt Mono-Wheel als offizielle Disziplin in das WM-Programm auf | publisher = ''Rhoenradturnen in Deutschland'' | date = 1 January 2012 | accessdate = 4 December 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130211164456/http://www.rhoenrad-dtb.de/2012/irv-nimmt-mono-wheel-in-wm-programm-auf.html | archivedate = 11 February 2013 | df = }}</ref> where it was referred to as the ''Einreifen'' or ''mono wheel'', having been developed by Adalbert von Rekowski as a variation on Otto Feick's popular ''[[Rhönrad]]'' (German wheel).<ref name="rekowski">{{Cite web | url = http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/rollendes-revival-fotostrecke-109934-7.html | title = Rollendes Revival: Das total durchgedrehte Ding | author = Gerlind Vollmer | publisher = ''Spiegel Online'' | date = 12 July 2007 | accessdate=28 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="monowheel"/>
Around 1996, the wheel was reinvented and developed as a circus apparatus by Daniel Cyr, a graduate of the [[École nationale de cirque|National Circus School in Montreal]] and co-founder of the [[contemporary circus]] troupe [[Cirque Éloize]].<ref name="inertie"/> Cyr claims the idea came to him from a large [[hula hoop]] and an old circular wrought-iron coat rack.<ref name="inertie"/> His design for the wheel went through several iterations, evolving from steel to aluminum, adding a PVC coating, and eventually implementing a multi-part design that could be disassembled for easier transportation.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/arts/circus-arts/cyr-wheel1.htm | title = History of Acrobatic Wheels - How the Cyr Wheel Works | publisher = HowStuffWorks.com | author = Dave Roos | date = 13 March 2015 | accessdate = 28 October 2015}}</ref> Cyr first performed with the apparatus in the Cirque Éloize production of ''Excentricus'',<ref name="inertie"/> which toured North America, Europe and Asia between 1997 and 2002. He subsequently presented a Cyr wheel circus act at the 2003 Festival Mondial du Cirque de Demain in [[Paris]] and won the Silver Medal for his performance.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Cyr Wheel / Daniel Cyr / Cirque Éloize|url=http://www.cirque-eloize.com/en/who-are-we/the-cyr-wheel}}</ref>
Since its recent popularization as a [[circus skill]], hundreds of circus artists from around the world have performed in the wheel and it is now taught in several major circus schools.<ref name="FEDEC"/> The USA Wheel Gymnastics Federation and the International Rhoenradturnen Verband, with significant assistance from coaches and athletes from the [[École Nationale de Cirque de Montréal]], developed rules for Cyr wheel competition. The first such competition was held in [[Chicago]] in October 2011 and the first world championships in Cyr wheel competition was held during the 10th World Championships in Wheel Gymnastics, July 7-14, 2013 in Chicago.
Professional [[circus school]]s that offer advanced training on the Cyr wheel include: the [[Ecole Supérieure des Arts du Cirque]] (ESAC) in Belgium, the [[National Centre for Circus Arts]] in the UK, the Centre national des arts du cirque (CNAC) in France, and the [[École nationale de cirque]] in Montreal.
Cyr wheels are typically made of stainless steel tubing or aluminum tubing approximately {{convert|1.5|in|mm}} in diameter. They are often composed of 3 or 5 individual pieces fixed together by steel or aluminum couplings. They may be painted and covered with an anti-slip plastic coating to add friction and protect the metal.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.corbinstreehouse.com/blog/2011/06/roue-cyr/ | title = Making a roue cyr | author = Corbin Dunn}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rhönradbau.de/en/cyr-wheel | title = Cyr Wheel | publisher = rhönradbau.de | accessdate = 28 October 2015 }}</ref><ref name="FEDEC"/>
Smaller wheels spin faster, work better for smaller spaces, and make "no hand" tricks easier than larger wheels. Larger wheels are more graceful and there is more room for suspensions.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.coggscircus.com/q-and-a-cyr-wheel/ | title = Cyr Wheel Q & A | publisher = Coggs' Circus | accessdate = 28 October 2015 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Wheel gymnastics]] * [[Monowheel]] * [[Wheel of Death (Space Wheel)|Wheel of Steel]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Cyr wheel}} * [http://www.wheel-sensation.com/news/cyr-wheel-mono-wheel/ "Cyr Wheel in Shows"] * [http://www.fedec.eu/datas/files/fedec_cyrwheelmanual_en_2011.pdf "Cyr Wheel".] European Federation of Professional Circus Schools (FEDEC). 2011. * {{HowStuffWorks|page=arts/circus-arts/cyr-wheel|name=How the Cyr Wheel Works}}
[[Category:Circus skills]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = DARK | image = DarkEU.jpg | collapsible = | state = | caption = European cover art | developer = [[Realmforge Studios]] | publisher = [[Kalypso Media]] | designer = Christian Wolfertstetter | director = Benjamin Rauscher | programmer = Korbinian Abenthum | artist = Victor Linke | series = | engine = [[Vision (game engine)|Vision]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.onlysp.com/latest-trailer-released-for-dark-a-cel-shaded-vampire-rpg/ | title = Latest trailer released for "DARK," a cel-shaded vampire RPG | work = OnlySP | first = Michael | last = Urban | date = 16 February 2013 | accessdate = 8 May 2013}}</ref> | released = {{Video game release|NA|July 3, 2013 <small>(PC)</small>|EU|July 5, 2013|NA|July 9, 2013 <small>(X360)</small>|AU|July 18, 2013}} | genre = [[Stealth game|Stealth]], [[Action role-playing game|action role-playing]]<ref name="gamerevolution">{{cite web | url = http://www.gamerevolution.com/news/vampire-rpg-dark-will-suck-hopefully-12737 | title = Vampire RPG DARK Will Suck, Hopefully | work = [[Game Revolution]] | first = Nicholas | last = Tan | date = 4 May 2011}}</ref> | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Xbox 360]] }}
'''''Dark''''' (stylized as '''''DARK''''') is a [[Stealth game|stealth]] [[Action role-playing game|action role-playing]] [[video game]] developed by German team [[Realmforge Studios]] and published by [[Kalypso Media]], released in July 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/2012/05/14/dark-is-a-stealth-game-with-vampires-sneaking-to-xbox-pc/ | title = Dark is a stealth game with vampires, sneaking to Xbox, PC | work = [[Engadget]] ([[Joystiq]]) | first = Richard | last = Mitchell | date = 14 May 2012 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> It was officially announced on May 4, 2012. A playable version of the game was presented at the 2012 [[Role Play Convention]] in [[Cologne]], [[Germany]]<ref name="gamerevolution"/> and the [[E3 2012]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgameshardware.de/aid,889777/Dark-E3-Vorschau/Action-Spiel/News/ | title = Vampir-Action mit Dark: Muss man das Schleich-Action-Adventure auf der Rechnung haben? Die E3-Vorschau | work = PC Games Hardware | first = Roland | last = Austinat | date = 10 June 2012 | accessdate = 11 June 2012 | language = de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamezone.com/previews/e3-2012-dark-preview | title = E3 2012: Dark preview | work = GameZone | first = David | last = Sanchez | date = 6 June 2012 | accessdate = 11 June 2012}}</ref>
A reveal trailer was released on May 24, 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zcnwrlNpLeI&feature=g-all-u | title = Teaser Trailer | work = [[YouTube]] | author = Machinima | date = 24 May 2012}}</ref>
==Gameplay== The gameplay of ''Dark'' is based on stealth combat. Eric has many supernatural vampiric 'skills' at his disposal; he can use Shadow Leap to quickly teleport to different areas and to perform stealth finishers, make himself temporarily invisible, see in the dark and slow down time. His abilities are linked to a certain amount of 'blood points' which are used up each time Eric uses a skill. He can drink blood from his enemies to restore his health and blood points.
==Plot== The game follows the story of Eric Bane ([[Doug Cockle]]), a newly turned vampire suffering from [[amnesia]]. He learns that his transformation is not complete and that, if he does not drink the blood of his sire, he will mutate into a mindless ghoul. In order to avoid being such a foul creature, he receives missions to drink ancient vampires' blood. However, an angel in Eric's view appears to guide him to the righteous path, and ease intolerable pain that comes from not drinking appropriate blood as it disappears. With a question of this vision, he tries to recover his deleted memories and his true self.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | PC = true | X360 = true | na = true | Edge_X360 = 3/10<ref>{{cite journal | title = Dark review (X360) | magazine = [[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] | author = Edge staff | date = 24 July 2013}}</ref> | EuroG_X360 = 3/10<ref name=eurog>{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-07-08-dark-review | title = Dark review (Xbox 360) | work = [[Eurogamer]] | first = Dan | last = Whitehead | date = 8 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | GI_X360 = 2/10<ref name=gi>{{cite web | url = http://www.gameinformer.com/games/dark/b/xbox360/archive/2013/07/09/a-vampire-who-sucks-at-everything.aspx | title = Dark (X360): A Vampire Who Sucks At Everything | work = [[Game Informer]] | first = Andrew | last = Reiner | date = 9 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | GSpot_PC = 3.5/10<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/dark-review/1900-6412133/ | title = DARK Review (PC) | work = [[GameSpot]] | first = Kevin | last = VanOrd | date = 26 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | GRadar_PC = {{Rating|2.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamesradar.com/dark-review/ | title = Dark review (PC) | work = [[GamesRadar]] | first = Mike | last = Suskie | date = 12 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | IGN_PC = 4/10<ref name=ign>{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/07/11/dark-review | title = Dark Review | work = [[IGN]] | first = Leif | last = Johnson | date = 11 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | IGN_X360 = 4/10<ref name=ign/> | OXM_X360 = 4.5/10<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.oxmonline.com/dark-review | title = Dark review | work = [[Official Xbox Magazine]] | first = Mikel | last = Reparaz | date = 24 July 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130726125255/http://www.oxmonline.com/dark-review | archivedate = 26 July 2013 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | OXMUK_X360 = 6/10<ref name=oxmuk>{{cite web | url = http://www.oxm.co.uk/57843/reviews/dark-xbox-360-review/ | title = DARK Xbox 360 Review | work = [[Official Xbox Magazine|Official Xbox Magazine UK]] | first = Jon | last = Blyth | date = 8 July 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130710184226/http://www.oxm.co.uk/57843/reviews/dark-xbox-360-review/ | archivedate = 10 July 2013 | deadurl = yes | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | PCGUK_PC = 43%<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/dark-review/ | title = Dark review | magazine = [[PC Gamer|PC Gamer UK]] | first = Richard | last = Cobbett | date = November 2013 | page = 68 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | Poly_PC = 3/10<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.polygon.com/2013/7/15/4525902/dark-review | title = Dark review: thin blood (PC) | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] | first = Philip | last = Kollar | date = 15 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | rev1 = ''The Digital Fix'' | rev1_X360 = 3/10<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gaming.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/1905/dark.html | title = Dark (X360) | work = The Digital Fix | first = Ryan | last = Poxon | date = 20 August 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' | rev2_X360 = {{Rating|2|5}}<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/editorials/reviews/10482-Dark-Review-C-Grade-Vampire-Noir | title = Dark Review - C-Grade Vampire Noir (X360) | work = [[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]] | first = Paul | last = Goodman | date = 19 July 2013 | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> | MC_PC = 41/100<ref name=mcpc>{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/dark | title = DARK for PC Reviews | work = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref> | MC_X360 = 38/100<ref name=mcx360>{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/dark | title = DARK for Xbox 360 Reviews | work = Metacritic | accessdate = 31 January 2016}}</ref> }}
''Dark'' received "generally unfavorable reviews" on both platforms according to video game [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]].<ref name=mcpc/><ref name=mcx360/> Much of the game's criticism has been aimed at the poor melee combat, camera, script, and lack of interest in the game's protagonist. In a mixed review, Jon Blythe of ''[[Official Xbox Magazine|Official Xbox Magazine UK]]'' stated: "''DARK'' is frustrating, because that initial feeling of being a zippy blur of a vampire in a world of neon-lit night never leaves you. It's just swamped in frustrating design decisions, a script that lurches from passable to laughable, weak enemy AI, and a vortex of a lead character who's impossible to like or hate."<ref name=oxmuk/> Dan Whitehead of [[Eurogamer]] stated that "low-budget games can be delightful and surprising, but only if the core elements work. Here, they don't. In its best moments, this is only ever a reminder of better games. In its worst moments - of which there are far too many - ''Dark'' frustrates and irritates as only a clumsy stealth game can."<ref name=eurog/>
Michael Engle of The Game Scouts said, "I would rather [insert cliché about how to kill a vampire here] than play this game."<ref name=gamescouts>{{cite web | url = http://www.thegamescouts.com/2013/07/dark-review.html | title = Dark Review | publisher = The Game Scouts | first = Michael | last = Engle | date = 12 July 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130715002049/http://www.thegamescouts.com/2013/07/dark-review.html | archivedate = 15 July 2013}}</ref>
In the most negative review on the website, Andrew Reiner of ''[[Game Informer]]'' complained that "I’ve played a lot of bad Xbox 360 games for achievements, but hardly any are as unpolished and poorly executed as ''Dark''. It’s easily one of this generation’s worst titles. Even when the stealth is working moderately well, the slow pacing is a killer, and no amount of blood sucking brings satisfaction. Most levels were completed through trial and error, failure after failure, and then success coming from exploiting an AI bug or an odd design decision."<ref name=gi/>

{{Infobox character | colour = #DEDEE2 | colour text = | name = Debbie Downer | series = [[Saturday Night Live]] | image = Debbie Downer.PNG | image_size = 215px | caption = | first = May 1, 2004 | last = February 15, 2015 | creator = | portrayer = [[Rachel Dratch]] | gender = Female }} '''Debbie Downer''' is a name of a fictional ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' character who debuted in 2004, and who was portrayed by [[Rachel Dratch]].
The character's name, [[wiktionary:Debbie Downer|Debbie Downer]], is a [[slang]] phrase which refers to someone who frequently adds bad news and negative feelings to a gathering, thus bringing down the mood of everyone around them. Dratch's character would usually appear at social gatherings and interrupt the conversation to voice negative opinions and pronouncements. She is especially concerned about the rate of [[Feline immunodeficiency virus|feline AIDS]], a subject that she would bring up on more than one occasion, saying it was the number one killer of domestic cats.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sims |first=David |date=May 1, 2014 |title=Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer,' Ten Years After Her Debut |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/05/remembering-every-second-of-debbie-downer-ten-years-after-her-debut/361518/ |work=The Atlantic |location=Boston, MA |ref={{sfnRef|"Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer'"}}}}</ref>
==First appearance in 2003–04 season== The first appearance of Debbie Downer was on May 1, 2004, with guest host [[Lindsay Lohan]].{{sfn|"Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer'"}} Debbie and five family members—played by Lohan, [[Jimmy Fallon]], Dratch, [[Amy Poehler]], [[Fred Armisen]], and [[Horatio Sanz]]—are eating breakfast at a restaurant in [[Walt Disney World]].{{sfn|"Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer'"}} While the family makes small talk, Debbie makes negative comments on current events followed by a knowing look at the camera and a cartoonish "[[wah-wah (music)|wah-wah]]" sound made by a [[Mute (music)|muted]] trombone.{{sfn|"Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer'"}}
In this sketch, everyone on camera [[corpsing|cracked up]] because of both the "wah-wah" sound effect and Dratch flubbing a line early on and correcting herself.{{sfn|"Remembering Every Second of 'Debbie Downer'"}} The sketch was listed at #99 as part of [[TV Land]]'s "Top 100 Most Unexpected Moments in TV History."{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
==2004–05 season== Debbie Downer appeared in a sketch in the 2004-05 season opener with [[Ben Affleck]] as the guest host. The cast members who appeared in this sketch were more composed and did not laugh out loud at Debbie's pronouncements. This trend continued throughout the rest of the season.
In future airings of the Affleck episode, the live Debbie Downer sketch was replaced by the dress rehearsal version, along with an opening title card explaining that the dress rehearsal "worked better." In the dress rehearsal, the cast all cracks up just as they did in the Lindsay Lohan episode.
The character appeared two more times that season: once at [[Thanksgiving]] dinner (with [[Luke Wilson]] as host) and another at the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|Oscars]] with [[Hilary Swank]] (playing herself). The latter sketch revealed that Debbie babysat Swank when Swank was a child. [[Will Forte]] appeared in the sketch as Swank's then-husband, [[Chad Lowe]].
==2005–06 season== In 2005, the season premiere of ''Saturday Night Live'' featured a Debbie Downer sketch at the end of the episode. Host [[Steve Carell]]'s character, '''Bob Bummer''', is just as negative, and he and Debbie fall in love.
The December 17, 2005, episode, hosted by [[Jack Black (actor)|Jack Black]], included a [[Christmas]]-themed sketch showing Debbie in her childhood during a visit from [[Santa Claus]]. This episode contradicts her debut sketch, as here she refers to her last name being "Downer."
On April 15, 2006, Debbie returned for her final appearance before Dratch departed the show, this time at a bachelorette party at a strip club in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] for her sister, played once again by host Lohan, despite not being invited in the first place. As with the very first sketch, there is one point when the orchestra mistakenly began playing the "wah-wah" sound effect at the wrong time.
==2010 appearance== During the May 8, 2010, episode hosted by [[Betty White]], there was a Debbie Downer sketch filmed during dress rehearsal, but it was cut from the live show due to time constraints.<ref>Soraya Roberts, [http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/nbc-releases-betty-white-un-aired-saturday-night-live-debbie-downer-sketch-article-1.178492 NBC releases Betty White's un-aired 'Saturday Night Live' 'Debbie Downer' sketch], ''New York Daily News'', (May 9, 2010).</ref> The episode is now posted on NBC.com's ''Saturday Night Live'' page, featuring video clips of old and new sketches from the show's 35-years-and-counting tenure. A group of suburban women (all played by the guest actresses listed in addition to then-current cast member [[Kristen Wiig]]) are having a lingerie party and, as usual, Debbie Downer ruins everyone's fun. One housewife (played by [[Amy Poehler]]) yells at Debbie and asks her why she's so miserable all the time. Downer thinks back to her childhood where during her birthday, her depressed grandmother (played by White) warns her not to enjoy her birthday cake because [[gluten]] allergies run in her family.
==2015 appearance== During the SNL 40th anniversary special, Dratch appears briefly at the beginning as Downer, telling the audience that starting a show with a musical performance decreases viewership.
==Theme song== Every sketch opened with a prologue, then the theme song (and corresponding video) plays, followed by the body of the sketch. The sketch would ultimately close with the last line of the song played again (and one more negative fact from Debbie). The song ends with an extreme close-up of Debbie's pained expression.
Theme song lyrics: "You're enjoying your day, everything's going your way, then along comes Debbie Downer. Always there to tell you 'bout a new disease, a car accident, or killer bees. You'll beg her to spare you, 'Debbie, please!' but you can't stop Debbie Downer!"
The Christmas sketch began with a special theme song. It featured an animated Debbie, looking much like ''[[How the Grinch Stole Christmas!|The Grinch Who Stole Christmas]]'', and a tune similar to the Grinch's song. Steve Carell's Bob Bummer also had his own theme song.
==''SNL'' episodes featuring Debbie Downer==

Date || Host |- | 2004-05-01 || Lindsay Lohan |- | 2004-10-02 || Ben Affleck |- | 2004-11-20 || Luke Wilson |- | 2005-02-19 || Hilary Swank |- | 2005-10-01 || Steve Carell (as Bob Bummer) |- | 2005-12-17 || Jack Black (Debbie Downer Christmas) |- | 2006-04-15|| Lindsay Lohan |- | 2010-05-08|| Betty White (unaired) |}

{{Infobox video game |image = |caption = Box art |developer = Raylight s.r.l. |publisher = [[Maximum Games]] |platforms = [[Nintendo 3DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Wii]], [[WiiWare]] |released = '''Nintendo 3DS'''
{{Video game release|NA|May 27, 2012|EU|August 13, 2013 {{small|(eShop only)}}}}'''Wii'''
{{Video game release|NA|November 16, 2012}}'''Microsoft Windows'''
{{Video game release|NA|November 16, 2012 {{small|(Retail)}}|WW|January 7, 2013 {{small|(Digital)}}}}'''WiiWare'''
{{Video game release|NA|November 19, 2013|EU|November 28, 2013}} |genre = [[Sports video game|Sports]] ([[Hunting]]) |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] }} '''''Deer Drive Legends''''' is a three-dimensional hunting video game, developed by Raylight s.r.l.{{cite web|url=http://www.raylightgames.com/2012/02/deer-drive-legends-3ds-official-press-release/|title=''Deer Drive Legends'' Official Press Release|publisher=Raylight Games|accessdate=7 May 2012}} This 3D hunting game was published by [[Maximum Games]] and released on the [[Nintendo 3DS]] in May 2012 for both retail and download via [[Nintendo eShop]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/deer-drive-legends-3d/ |title=''Deer Drive Legends'' Tech Info |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=7 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503062303/http://www.gamespot.com/deer-drive-legends-3d/ |archivedate=3 May 2012 |df= }} It was later ported as a [[Wii]] and retail [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] PC game, and released in November 2012. The PC version was re-titled as '''''Deer Hunt Legends'''''. Unexpectedly, the Wii version of the game was eventually re-released as a [[WiiWare]] title on November 19, 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2013/11/nintendo_download_14th_november_north_america |title=Nintendo Download: 14th November (North America) |first=Thomas |last=Whitehead |publisher=Nintendo Life |date=2013-11-14 |accessdate=2013-11-15}} the first WiiWare title ever since ''[[Retro City Rampage]]'' launched on the platform in February 2013. The PC version became available in Europe via digital distribution when it was released globally on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] in January 2013. The Nintendo 3DS and WiiWare versions of the game were released in Europe in August and November 2013 respectively, wherein the Nintendo 3DS version is exclusively an eShop downloadable with a reduced price.{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2013/08/nintendo_download_8th_august_europe |title=Nintendo Download: 8th August (Europe) |first=Thomas |last=Whitehead |publisher=Nintendo Life |date=2013-08-05 |accessdate=2013-11-15}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2013/11/nintendo_download_28th_november_europe |title=Nintendo Download: 28th November (Europe) |first=Thomas |last=Whitehead |publisher=Nintendo Life |date=2013-11-25 |accessdate=2013-11-26}} ''Deer Drive Legends'' is rated T for Teens by the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jWeamyK9tt8|title=''Deer Drive Legends'' Official Trailer|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=7 May 2012}} ''Deer Drive Legends'' has little relation to the [[Deer Drive (2007 video game)|2007 ''Deer Drive'']] and [[Deer Drive (2009 video game)|2009 ''Deer Drive'']] games, other than having similar titles and [[deer hunting]] concepts. ==Setting== ''Deer Drive Legends'' takes place in numerous locations throughout the world, including the African Savannah, [[Rocky Mountains]], and [[Great Lakes]]. Players will explore famed hunting regions across four continents in search of the biggest trophy.{{cite web|url=http://gamasutra.com/view/pressreleases/82721/Deer_Drive_Legends.php|title=''Deer Drive Legends'' |publisher=Gamasutra|accessdate=7 May 2012}} ===Animals=== Players will take down a number of elusive animals such as bears, antelope, elk, deer, moose, and mountain lions. The game also features prehistoric species such as the [[Smilodon]], [[T-Rex]], and [[Gastornis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendo-x2.com/news/view/23799/more-3d-hunting-with-deer-drive-legends|title=More hunting with ''Deer Drive Legends'' |publisher=Nintendo-x2.com|accessdate=7 May 2012}} ==References== [[Category:2012 video games]] [[Category:Hunting video games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS eShop games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:WiiWare games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] {{sports-videogame-stub}}

__NOTOC__ [[Image:Devil's torture chamber illusion.jpg|right|thumb|A performance of ''The Devil's Torture Chamber'' by magician Guy Kent on a British TV show from the 1970s]] The '''Devil's Torture Chamber''' is a magic [[magic (illusion)|stage illusion]] of the classic type involving a female [[magician's assistant]] in a large box and is probably best categorised as a [[magic (illusion)#Penetration|penetration]] or [[magic (illusion)#Restoration|restoration-type]] illusion.
==Description== The magician presents an upright cabinet that is just big enough to hold a person with a little space above their head. The magician then presents a rack of metal spikes. Spectators are offered the chance to tap the spikes with a metal implement to prove they are real and solid. The spikes are fitted into the top of the cabinet pointing downwards. An assistant is introduced and steps into the cabinet. The door is closed and the spikes are forced downwards using handles that protrude through slots in the side of the cabinet. The implication is that the assistant must have been impaled by the spikes. However the door is opened to reveal the assistant alive and unharmed.
There are several slight variations. Sometimes the assistant carries a string of inflated balloons when he or she steps into the cabinet. These are burst as the spikes descend to give an added audible dimension to the illusion. Another description has a small door opened to show the assistant alive when the spikes are at the bottom of the cabinet; the small door is then closed again and the spikes lifted to the top before the assistant is finally fully revealed.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://hamiltonholtinc.stores.yahoo.net/devtorcham.html |title = ''Devil's Torture Chamber'' |publisher = Osbourne illusion systems website |accessdate = 2007-03-06}}</ref>
French magician Don José de Murcia performs a version of this illusion under the title "La Herse Infernal".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.donjosedemurcia.com/show.php |title = "Shows" page |publisher = Don José de Murcia website |accessdate = 2007-03-06}}</ref>
==History== The illusion is thought to be the creation of Floyd Thayer, founder of the Thayer Magic Company. Blueprints for it appeared in the Thayer catalog #7 supplement, which dates it to the early 1930s.
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== * ''The Great illusions of Magic'', pub. Louis Tannen (1977) * ''Keep the Wheels Turning'', pub. Owen's Magic Supreme (1977) * Paul Osbourne, ''Illusion Systems: Book 1'' * [[Derek Lever]], ''Jack Hughes World of Magic: Vol. 2'', p. 160, pub. Taurus Magic
==External links== * A listing for [http://hamiltonholtinc.stores.yahoo.net/devtorcham.html Plans for the ''Devil's Torture Chamber''] on the [http://hamiltonholtinc.stores.yahoo.net ''Osbourne Illusion Systems''] website
{{Magic and Illusion}}
[[Category:Magic tricks]]

{{expand Korean|아기공룡 둘리|date=April 2014}} {{Multiple issues| {{Lead too short|date=July 2012}} {{primary sources|date=December 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=December 2011}} }}
'''''Dooly the Little Dinosaur''''' ({{lang-ko|아기공룡 둘리}}) is a 1987 South Korean cartoon and animated film created by [[Kim Soo-jung]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.br/books?id=de5pBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=dolly+the+little+dinosaur&source=bl&ots=Cqv5OAcRBC&sig=EpUM854XERYB6pdV44ZrtLNCBA4&hl=pt-BR&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisrY-Tlp3TAhXLE5AKHT5pBZoQ6AEIdDAO#v=onepage&q=dolly%20the%20little%20dinosaur&f=false|title=K-Animation: Befriending Children All Over the World|last=Tourism|first=Korean Culture and Information Service Ministry of Culture, Sports and|last2=Hyung-suk|first2=Kim|date=2013-12-01|publisher=길잡이미디어|isbn=9788973755813|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170412062134/https://books.google.com.br/books?id=de5pBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA54&lpg=PA54&dq=dolly+the+little+dinosaur&source=bl&ots=Cqv5OAcRBC&sig=EpUM854XERYB6pdV44ZrtLNCBA4&hl=pt-BR&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisrY-Tlp3TAhXLE5AKHT5pBZoQ6AEIdDAO#v=onepage&q=dolly%20the%20little%20dinosaur&f=false|archivedate=2017-04-12|df=}}</ref> Dooly is one of the most respected and commercially successful characters of South Korean [[animation]]. Dooly became the first cartoon character to be featured on a [[postal stamp|stamp]]. It was printed in 1995 in [[South Korea]]. Dooly also has a resident registration card, which means he is a citizen of South Korea.
== History == Dooly ({{lang-ko|둘리}}) was first created when its creator [[Kim Soo-jung|Soo-Jung Kim]] issued the [[manhwa]] (cartoon in Korean) under the [[takubon|comic book]] named ''Bo-Mool Sum (Treasure Island)''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/People/view?articleId=120343|title=Father of Dooly, comic artist Kim Soo-jung :: Korea.net : The official website of the Republic of Korea|last=(KOCIS)|first=Korean Culture and Information Service|access-date=2017-04-11|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831174851/http://www.korea.net/NewsFocus/People/view?articleId=120343|archivedate=2017-08-31|df=}}</ref> It was first shown in the first week of April 1983, and ended about ten years later. There are two [[Spin-off (media)|spin-offs]] of the manhwa, one of which is still being published today.
The original animation and airing were done by South Korean [[Broadcasting|broadcaster]] [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]]. When it was first broadcast in 1987, there were only six episodes, with seven more added later during the second season. A [[video cassette]] was released in 1989, and re-broadcasting was first done in 1990.
The show was rebroadcast in 1993, 1996 and 1998, but due to the choice of inappropriate broadcasting dates (usually on Sunday), its recognizance and the viewer rating were critically low. In October 1998, however, [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]] noticed the increased viewership, and the broadcasting time was changed to 5:30 p.m. Monday and Tuesday (known as the 'Golden Viewing Time') starting May 12 through June 23, 2003. With more people watching the show, its ratings improved. A new version of the TV series, which began broadcasting in 2009, is currently shown Monday through Friday, at 4:00 PM on the Korean Animation channel [[Tooniverse]], Korea's first all-anime/manhwa channel.
The cartoon was once reported to the officials as a bad example for children because of the use of Dooly's care-giver's name in a friendly fashion. Koreans usually speak to adults with respect and with the use of proper additions in speech done so specifically for adults by younger people. This was seen as hazardous for the basic thinking of the children who watch it.
Tooniverse also released an [[educational]] English dub in 1995, and a theatrical release came out in 1996 under [[Dooly Nara]] (Dooly Nation).
==Characters== *'''Dooly''' is a baby [[dinosaur]] that was kidnapped by [[Extraterrestrials in fiction|alien]]s, who had experimented to give him magical powers. When he returned to [[Earth]], he was trapped in an [[glacier|ice glacier]] causing him to faint during the [[Ice Age]]. About 100 million years later, one of the glaciers broke off and he came to [[Seoul]]. Standing 4 feet and 6 inches tall, Dooly is a ''[[Ceratosaurus]]'' with an oversized head, meant to draw attention toward the character's facial expression, which he rarely changes. He has a tail as long as his height, and he sometimes uses it to make himself look taller than other characters, usually [[Ko Gildong|Kildong Go]]. He displays many human-like characteristics, including a habit of sticking out his tongue. His underside is full-white, as are his hands and feet. He has three toes per foot, and has five fingers on each hand, unlike a real ''[[Ceratosaurus]]'' which has four. He also has shiny white teeth. He is like a typical kid who likes to eat and play all the time, but he can come across as being somewhat audacious, living the life of an orphan. Behind his thoughtful words, Dooly is just another baby dinosaur who misses his mother dinosaur. While in Seoul, he was found by a girl named ''Younghee'' ({{lang-ko|영희}}), and because she mistook Dooly for a dog she took him home with her and her elder brother ''Chulsoo'' (철수), and made him live with her as a pet. However, her father ''Kildong'' ({{lang-ko|고길동}}) hates Dooly and just beats Dooly up whenever he is annoying. Dooly has superpowers that he received from an extraterrestrial, but doesn't know why. He doesn't quite know how to use it deliberately but in times of danger, he somehow manages to use the power. He points his right finger and yells 'Hoihoi!' He is always biting his tongue and looking silly, but he is both mischievous and loyal. Once in a while, he'll resist, like when he turns Kildong into a dinosaur and sends him to the [[Amazon River|Amazon]], but whenever he does, it always turns against him. Dooly's name, according to the cartoon, is a [[pun]]. His older sister - Dooly called her 'brother' because he confused that exact nominal - is named ''Hana'', meaning '''One''' or '''First''' while ''Dool'', or ''Dul'' mean '''Two''' in Korean and ''y'' or ''ei'' mean the same thing in [[hanja|Korean Traditional-Chinese]], making him the '''Second'''. This is mentioned around the end of then 2nd set of episodes, or the 6th episode, but it is not certain if this is true in manhwa [[Canon (fiction)|canon]] due to the [[manhwa|anime and manhwa]] having many storyline differences. While Dooly is having adventures in Seoul and having fun, he meets three friends who Kildong hates too and beats up, all except ''Heedong'' (희동). *'''Go Heedong''' ({{lang-ko|고희동}}) came to live with Uncle Kildong after his parents went abroad to study. He misses his mom every day, but feels utterly entertained by Dooly the Brother. Thanks to the excessive amounts of time he spends with Dooly, he isn't afraid of anything. He is also really good at biting or scratching someone when they make him mad. He has broken Douner's Time Cosmos' [[spacecraft|Spaceship]]. *'''Douner''' ({{lang-ko|도우너}}) the Prince of [[Planet]] 'Kanttappia' makes an emergency landing on the planet [[Earth]] due to the malfunctioning of the 'Time Cosmos' Spaceship. His head may be really hard and his thoughts very simple, but the word "loyalty" was made for Douner. He can travel back and forth in time and space in the Time Cosmos Spaceship which looks like a [[violin]]. *'''Ddochi''' ({{lang-ko|또치}}), the [[Ostrich]] that successfully escaped from a [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]] [[circus]] troop, always insists that she used to be a noble mistress from [[Africa]]. She is a little bit selfish, and a little bit shy, but Ddochi is the most softhearted ostrich that anyone will ever come across. She also insists on calling herself a girl. Ddochi has many talents she learned from the [[circus]]. *'''Michol''' ({{lang-ko|마이콜}}, pronounced as "Maikol") is an aspiring singer who lives next to Kildong, and feeds on his passion for dreaming, though he may lack the necessary talent. He is quite lost most of the time, but does know how to take care of himself. Although he is South Korean, his appearance is noticeable different. His surname is Ma. According to his name, his role model is [[Michael Jackson]]. Dooly once joined a band with Douner and Michol.
==Controversy== When Dooly was first created as a [[TV]] animation, it received a lot of criticism from South Korean [[Catholics]],{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} South Korean citizens, and the [[government of South Korea|government]]. Reasons cited included the fact that the animation was a bit violent, which was suppressed by the South Korean government, and the adult general public was angered due to its character's attitude of disrespect towards elders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.jtbc.joins.com/article/article.aspx?news_id=NB11016499|title=둘리도 금서가 될 뻔했다?…9월 첫 주 '금서읽기주간'|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}</ref> However, this was when [[freedom of speech]] was not seriously taken into account. Generally speaking, the younger generation has fond memories of this series and find that the violence is actually a quite realistic portrayal of family dynamics in contemporary South Korea.
The character "Michol" has also received criticism in more recent years due to the character's appearance being likened to blackface.
==List of episodes== ===Original series (1987–1988)=== # "The Birth of Dooly" ({{lang-ko|둘리의 탄생}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "Grand Park Disturbance" ({{lang-ko|대공원 소동}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "My Friends" ({{lang-ko|내 친구들}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "Hyeongah! Do Not Go" ({{lang-ko|형아! 가지 마}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "Travel to the Past: Part 1" ({{lang-ko|과거로의 여행 (상)}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "Travel to the Past: Part 2" ({{lang-ko|과거로의 여행 (하)}}; original airdate: October 7, 1987) # "Dooly's Anger" ({{lang-ko|둘리의 분노}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "Michol's Debut" ({{lang-ko|마이콜 등장}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "Ddochi's Escape" ({{lang-ko|또치의 탈출}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "The Strange Lamp" ({{lang-ko|이상한 램프}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "Dooly's Miniature" ({{lang-ko|둘리 소인국}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "The Invaders from the Squid Planet: Part 1" ({{lang-ko|꼴뚜기 별의 왕자님 (상)}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988) # "The Invaders from the Squid Planet: Part 2" ({{lang-ko|꼴뚜기 별의 왕자님 (하)}}; original airdate: May 5, 1988)

{{Infobox video game | title = Duet | italic title = | collapsible = | state = | image = | caption = | developer = [[Kumobius]] | publisher = | series = | engine = | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Linux]], [[OS X]], [[Windows]] | released = 10 October 2013<ref name="metacritic"/> | genre = [[Action game|Action]] | modes = | director = | producer = | designer = | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = | cabinet = | arcade system = | cpu = | sound = | display = }} '''''Duet''''' is a 2013 [[action game]] by Australian game developer Kumobius for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].<ref name="pocketgamer"/><ref name="gamezebohumble"/> Players control two coloured orbs, guiding them to avoid incoming obstacles. Its Android version was first released as a part of [[Humble Bundle|Humble Mobile Bundle 6]].<ref name="gamezebohumble"/>
== Gameplay == The player rotates a circular track with two coloured orbs, guiding the balls to avoid incoming obstacles.<ref name="maclife"/><ref name="kotakuau"/> The level is reset once an orb crashes into an obstacle.<ref name="maclife"/> It's required to keep both orbs intact to pass a level.<ref name="gamezebo"/> The names of the levels are from the [[Kübler-Ross model]].<ref name="toucharcade"/>
== Reception == The game has gathered mixed to positive reviews from critics. As of August 2014, [[Metacritic]] lists a score of 79 for the game, a rating of "Generally favorable reviews".<ref name="metacritic"/> ''Duet'' is also listed a score of 80.00% on [[GameRankings]].<ref name="gamerankings"/> Critics praise ''Duet'' for its controls and design, yet noting its notorious difficulty.<ref name="pocketgamer"/><ref name="gamezebo"/><ref name="toucharcade"/><ref name="edge"/>

<!-- Gamezebo: 4.5/5 stars --> <ref name="gamezebo">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezebo.com/2013/10/14/duet-review/|title=Duet Review|author=Mike Rose|work=[[Gamezebo]]|date=14 October 2013}}</ref>
<!-- Edge: 6/10 --> <ref name="edge">{{cite web|url=http://www.edge-online.com/review/duet-review/|title=Duet review|work=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|date=17 October 2013}}</ref>

{{italic title}} {{about||the Polish village|Dymer, Poland|the Ukrainian town|Dymer, Kiev Oblast}} {{Original research|date=January 2011}} [[File:Dymer.jpg|thumb|First edition]]
'''''Dymer''''' is a [[narrative poem]] by [[C. S. Lewis]]. He worked on this, his most important poem, as early as 1916—when still only 17 years old—and completed it in 1925. ''Dymer'' was his second published work;<ref>[http://cslewismadison.org/fiction.html]</ref> it was published by [[J. M. Dent]] in 1926, under the pseudonym Clive Hamilton (the writer's actual first name followed by his mother's maiden name).
Lewis thought of himself as writing in the tradition of [[Homer]], [[Edmund Spenser|Spenser]], [[John Milton|Milton]], [[Wordsworth]], and others. [[George Sayer]]'s analysis suggests that the book is about the temptation of fantasies, "the fantasies of love, lust, and power."
==Plot overview== ''Dymer'' follows the adventures of its titular protagonist from his birth in a totalitarian state, mockingly referred to as 'The Perfect City', to the events leading to his death at the hands of a monster he begat.
From the opening, Dymer grows to the age of nineteen under the control of the state, until, under the influence of spring and the sight of a songbird, he rises in his lecture-hall and murders the aged lecturer before his class, then leaves the stunned civilians behind as he wanders outside The City.
Dymer casts off his clothing along with civilization, wandering in the forests until he comes upon an empty mansion with food prepared. After dressing himself again with finer clothing, and feasting alone at a banquet table, Dymer sleeps with an unseen female figure who comes to him in the darkness of the mansion. Upon awakening, Dymer steps outside of the palace and wanders blissfully in the woods. Returning to the palace in search of his lover, he finds every entry barred by a hideous old she-monster. After pleading with her to 'yield but one inch; once only from your law', Dymer approaches the woman with intent to fight his way past her. What happens at this point is uncertain, except that Dymer emerges wounded from the palace and limps into the woodlands.
It begins to rain that night in the woods, and Dymer encounters yet another person he cannot see in the dark, this time a wounded man. This man also hails from The Perfect City, and tells Dymer of what happened in his absence, specifically that a revolutionary named Bran used Dymer's actions and name to instill violent protest in the citizens, who then went on to sack and raze the city. Dymer is dumbfounded at this information, and stays silent in the night until the man's wounds prove fatal, then sets out again for the wilderness.
Dymer encounters another individual in the wilderness, a man who uses a liquid to put himself into an extended dreaming state. Convincing Dymer that the answer to his anguish is in the dreaming world, Dymer swallows a cup of the liquid. In his hallucination, Dymer encounters his former lover from the mansion, but realizes she is monstrous. Instead of accepting this as the truth, he flees the scene as demons rise to assault him. Upon awakening, Dymer is threatened by the dreaming man, and sets off into the wilderness again. Dymer later arrives at a cemetery where he encounters an angelic guardian, who tells Dymer of a horrible monster lurking about, who was conceived by a union between a divine being and a mortal. Realizing that the beast is his own offspring, Dymer states he must face his own son in battle. Donning the guardian's armor, he prepares to fight the monster, which ends in his own death and the beast becoming a god.
== Bibliography == # Hodgens, Richard. "Notes on ''Narrative Poems''." ''CSL: The Bulletin of the New York C. S. Lewis Society''. 7 no. 78 (April 1976): 1–14. # King, Don W. ''Dymer''. ''The C. S. Lewis Readers' Encyclopedia''. Pages 144–146. # Lewis, C. S. Preface to the 1950 edition of ''Narrative Poems''. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1950. # Murphy, Patrick. "C. S. Lewis's ''Dymer'': One More with Hesitation." ''CSL: The Bulletin of the New York C. S. Lewis Society''. 17 no. 200 (June 1986): 1–8. # Sayer, George. "C. S. Lewis's ''Dymer''." ''VII: An Anglo-American Literary Review''. 1980. # Slack, Michael. "Sehnsucht and the Platonic Eros in ''Dymer''." ''CSL: The Bulletin of the New York C. S. Lewis Society''. 11 no. 130 (August 1980): 3–7. # Walsh, Chad. ''The Literary Legacy of C. S. Lewis''. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1979.

[[File:Edmondo Zacchini and Hugo Zacchini 1960-1970 circa.jpg|thumb]] '''Edmondo Zacchini''' (27 March 1894 – 3 October 1981) was a circus entertainer credited with inventing the [[human cannonball]] act as one of the [[Zacchini Brothers]].<ref name=ap/>
==Early life== Edmondo Zacchini was the oldest son of [[Ildebrando Zacchini]], an [[Italy|Italian]] portrait [[artist]] and amateur [[gymnast]], and brother of [[Hugo Zacchini]]. Ildebrando brought his family up in a traveling [[circus]]. The family eventually formed their own [[circus]], and Edmondo became a gifted [[clown]], as well as doing acrobatics.
==Pagnotta== During [[World War I]], when food was hard to come by, Edmondo was walking through town when he was recognized by a townsman. The man had enjoyed the act so much, that he gave Edmondo his [[pagnotta]], a small loaf of bread that was, at the time, rationed by the [[bakery]] to one loaf per person. Others came up, and each gave him their bread in appreciation for the act. From then on, when the townspeople saw him, they would say "There goes Pagnotta". Edmondo adopted it as his stage name. With this name, he became the most famous [[clown]] in [[Italy]] in the 1920s.
==Human Cannonball==
He developed his first [[human cannonball]] act in [[Cairo]] in 1922. This cannon was a crude spring-powered contraption that hurled him 20 feet. The result of his first attempt was a broken leg. He re-designed the device in a [[hospital]] in [[Cairo]]. Later successful versions used [[compressed air]].
Zacchini and his brother Vittorio were invited to the [[United States]] in 1930 by a circus promoter. The family, consisting of six brothers and two sisters, eventually settled in [[Florida]], becoming citizens of the [[United States]].
==Death == Zacchini died in a hospital at the age of 87.<ref name=ap>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Edmondo Zacchini, Inventor Of Human Cannonball Act, 87 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9803E2DE1239F934A35753C1A967948260 |quote= Edmondo Zacchini, credited with inventing the ''Human Cannonball'' circus act by firing himself out of a spring-powered cannon, died here in a hospital Saturday. He was 87 years old. Mr. Zacchini developed his act in Cairo in 1922 using a crude spring-powered cannon that hurled him 20 feet. He later developed one using compressed air. The first time he was shot from the cannon, he broke a leg and redesigned the device in the hospital. Mr. Zacchini and his brother Vittorio came to the United States in 1930 at the invitation of a circus promoter; eventually the family settled here. Their act involved six brothers and two sisters. |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 7, 1981 |accessdate=2008-08-04 }}</ref> He is buried in a mausoleum in the [[Showman's Rest Cemetery]], [[Tampa]], [[Florida]].
==External links== * [http://yesterdaystowns.blogspot.com/2006_10_01_archive.html This is Pagnotta] * {{Find a Grave|7079335}}
==References== {{reflist}}
